The U.S. Drought Monitor map, which provides this data, is updated weekly. forecast.status_quo_outcome: Yes - the question would resolve as Yes if current conditions persist, as 22.7 million residents are currently living in drought areas, which exceeds the 20 million threshold
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Significant rainfall in June leads to rapid improvement in drought conditions, causing the U.S. Drought Monitor to reclassify affected areas such that fewer than 20 million California residents remain in drought-designated zones
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Drought conditions persist or worsen over the next 30 days, maintaining the current status where over 22.7 million residents live in drought areas, or conditions remain relatively stable through the dry summer season
forecast.rationale: The current data shows 22.7 million California residents in drought areas as of May 27, 2025, which is 2.7 million above the 20 million threshold (a 13.5% buffer). With only 30 days until resolution and the U.S. Drought Monitor updating weekly, there will be approximately 4-5 updates before June 28. Several factors strongly favor a Yes outcome: (1) California typically experiences its dry season from late spring through summer, with June being historically one of the driest months; (2) Droughts evolve slowly and rarely resolve within a month without extraordinary precipitation; (3) The status quo bias principle suggests conditions are unlikely to change dramatically in 30 days. While the March data showing 86% full Lake Oroville and 96% snowpack indicates decent water storage, this doesn't immediately translate to drought designation changes, which depend on recent precipitation patterns and current moisture conditions. For a No outcome to occur, California would need unusual and substantial June rainfall to reduce drought-affected populations by at least 2.7 million worth of area - historically uncommon for this time of year. My forecast is not higher (95%+) because weather can be unpredictable and there's always some uncertainty in 30-day forecasts, plus the Drought Monitor classification system could shift. It's not lower because the current buffer above threshold is substantial and the seasonal timing strongly disfavors drought relief. I would update upward if June weather forecasts show persistent dry conditions, or downward if significant rainfall systems are predicted for California in June.
